title: Racist yobs throw bleach and make monkey noises at woman in drive-by attack
text:
Reem Fahad is sure the attack was inspired by racist Bulgarian football fans (Picture: Mercury Press)

Racist thugs lobbed bleach and shouted monkey noises as they drove past a support worker on her way to help a patient with dementia.

Reem Fahad, 24, believes the drive-by attack was inspired by Bulgarian football fans, whose hateful chanting nearly led to Monday’s match against England being cancelled.

She was walking down a main road in Horwich, Bolton, at 1.30pm yesterday when the corrosive substance was thrown at her from a passing black car.

Manchester born Reem had her headphones on and was looking at her phone for Christmas presents for her three-year-old son King as she made her way to see her client.

The mixed race mother-of-one said: ‘I thought it was acid at first but it didn’t burn through straight away.

The bleach burned through her work clothes, but she went ahead with the appointment with her client anyway (Picture: Mercury Press)

‘It looked like young white lads in the car and they were making money noises at me – it was disgusting.

‘If my little boy had been there he would have been right in the line of the window where the lads threw the bleach and it might have got him.

‘I presume it’s football that’s kicked all this off and I think that alcohol was involved because the lads were loud, it’s ridiculous.’

Reem says she would have confronted the men if she had the chance (Picture: Mercury Press)

Reem put her job first and went straight to help her client before calling the police to report the incident an hour later.

By this point, the bleach had stained through her clothing and began to irritate her skin.

She said: ‘I would have confronted the men if I could have – it won’t stop me from going to work.

She teaches her three-year-old son King ‘to be proud and understanding’ (Picture: Mercury Press)

‘I grew up in Manchester in the 90s so I have experienced racism pretty much all my life and I think that this attack just goes to show that racism hasn’t gone away, it’s still there.

‘How can I teach my son to be proud and understanding when this is the ignorance people still have?’

Greater Manchester Police took Reem’s clothes for testing and are now appealing for witnesses.

In a statement, the forced confirmed the incident was believed to be racially motivated.

Reem has since been ‘inundated’ with supportive messages (Picture: Mercury Press)

Reem is now back at work and hopes her attackers will be found and brought to justice soon.

She added: ‘I’m not scared but I don’t want it to happen to anyone else, so I hope these people are found as soon as possible.

‘I feel sorry for the ignorance and lack of education these men have and I hope nobody ever singles them out for the colour of their skin.

‘I’ve never experienced racism in Horwich before but I’ve been inundated with messages and I really appreciate the support.

‘It’s angered a lot of people, including my partner, but I don’t want it to become a fight.

‘I want to fight hate with love and understanding.’
